source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk1
evidence_span: Zirconium alloys are susceptible to a stable cracking process called delayed hydride cracking (DHC).

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk1
evidence_span: DHC has two stages: (a) crack initiation that requires a minimum crack driving force (the threshold stress intensity factor, $K _ { I H } )$ and $( b )$ stable crack growth that is weakly dependent on $K _ { I }$

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk1
evidence_span: DHC properties were measured on a number of components, made from the two-phase alloy $z _ { \mathrm { r } - 2 . 5 \mathrm { N b } }$ , irradiated at temperatures in the range of 250 to $2 9 0 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { C }$ in fast neutron fluxes $( E \ge 1 \ \mathbf { M e V } )$ between $1 . 6 \times 1 0 ^ { 1 7 }$ and $1 . 8 \times 1 0 ^ { 1 8 } \mathrm { { n / m ^ { 2 } \cdot s } }$ to fluences between $0 . 0 1 \times 1 0 ^ { 2 5 }$ and $9 . 8 \times 1 0 ^ { 2 5 } \mathrm { n } / \mathrm { m } ^ { 2 }$

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk1
evidence_span: DHC properties were measured on a number of components, made from the two-phase alloy $z _ { \mathrm { r } - 2 . 5 \mathrm { N b } }$ , irradiated at temperatures in the range of 250 to $2 9 0 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { C }$ in fast neutron fluxes $( E \ge 1 \ \mathbf { M e V } )$ between $1 . 6 \times 1 0 ^ { 1 7 }$ and $1 . 8 \times 1 0 ^ { 1 8 } \mathrm { { n / m ^ { 2 } \cdot s } }$ to fluences between $0 . 0 1 \times 1 0 ^ { 2 5 }$ and $9 . 8 \times 1 0 ^ { 2 5 } \mathrm { n } / \mathrm { m } ^ { 2 }$

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk1
evidence_span: The neutron irradiation reduced $K _ { I H }$ by about $20 \%$

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk1
evidence_span: and increased the velocity of cracking by a factor of about five.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk1
evidence_span: The increase in crack velocity was greatest with the lowest irradiation temperature.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk1
evidence_span: X-ray diffraction analyses showed that the degree of $\beta$ -phase decomposition was highest with an irradiation temperature of ${ \bf 2 9 0 ^ { \circ } C }$

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk1
evidence_span: while <a>-type dislocation densities were highest with an irradiation temperature of $2 5 0 \mathrm { ‰}$ .

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk1
evidence_span: Pressure tubes in CANDU reactors are made from $\mathbf { Z } \mathbf { r } \mathbf { - } 2 . 5 \mathbf { N } \mathbf { b }$ alloy by hot extrusion of hollow billets followed by $25 \%$ cold work.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk1
evidence_span: The extrusion process results in a crystallographic texture with the following resolved basal pole fractions: 0.32 (radial), 0.61 (transverse), and 0.07 (axial).

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk1
evidence_span: The extrusion process results in a crystallographic texture with the following resolved basal pole fractions: 0.32 (radial), 0.61 (transverse), and 0.07 (axial).

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk1
evidence_span: The extrusion process results in a crystallographic texture with the following resolved basal pole fractions: 0.32 (radial), 0.61 (transverse), and 0.07 (axial).

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk1
evidence_span: The pressure tubes are about $6 \textrm { m }$ long and have an inside diameter of $1 0 3 ~ \mathrm { m m }$ and a wall thickness $4 . 1 \ \mathrm { m m }$ .

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk1
evidence_span: The pressure tubes are about $6 \textrm { m }$ long and have an inside diameter of $1 0 3 ~ \mathrm { m m }$ and a wall thickness $4 . 1 \ \mathrm { m m }$ .

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk1
evidence_span: The pressure tubes are about $6 \textrm { m }$ long and have an inside diameter of $1 0 3 ~ \mathrm { m m }$ and a wall thickness $4 . 1 \ \mathrm { m m }$ .

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk1
evidence_span: Zr-2.5Nb material was also irradiated in a high flux reactor (OSIRIS) at Centre d'Etudes Nucleaires de Saclay.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk1
evidence_span: Two materials were used for this irradiation: standard, cold-worked $\mathbf { Z r } { - } 2 . 5 \mathbf { N b }$ (tube H737) and $\mathbf { Z r } \mathbf { - } 2 . 5 \mathbf { N } \mathbf { b }$ material produced by a modified route, TG3R1

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk1
evidence_span: The TG3R1 pressure tubes were produced using a lower extrusion ratio and higher percent coldwork than standard pressure tubes, and had an extra stress relieve at ${ 5 0 0 ^ { \circ } } \mathbf { C }$ for $^ { 6 \mathrm { ~ h ~ } }$ after cold drawing.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk1
evidence_span: About 1 atomic percent of hydrogen was added gaseously to these materials prior to irradiation.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk2
evidence_span: Cracks were started in CB specimens from $0 . 5 \mathrm { \cdot m m }$ -deep notches machined on the inside surface.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk2
evidence_span: hydrogen was added to some specimens electrolytically to allow testing up to ${ \bf 2 9 0 ^ { \circ } C }$

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk2
evidence_span: the maximum peak test temperature in irradiated material should not be greater than the irradiation temperature plus $1 0 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { C }$

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk2
evidence_span: The cracks were grown from about 0.5 to $2 . 0 \ \mathrm { m m }$

evidence_span: no further indications are obtained for at least $^ { 2 4 \ \mathbf { h } }$

evidence_span: The microstructure of cold-worked Zr-2.5Nb consists of flat, $\pmb { \alpha }$ -zirconium grains surrounded by thin layers of continuous $\beta$ zirconium

evidence_span: Specimens for analysis by XRD were prepared by cutting thin slices from the tube perpendicular to each of the three principal tube axes, that is, longitudinal normal (LN), transverse normal (TN), radial normal (RN)

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk3
evidence_span: In the R/J region, the crack velocity increased rapidly with fluence, Figs. 5 and 6.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk3
evidence_span: The results from the end-of-life irradiations (TRILLIUM and ERABLE) showed a weak dependence of the crack velocity on fluence, Fig. 6.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk3
evidence_span: In specimens from the main bodies of pressure tubes, the crack velocity was three to five times higher than that of unirradiated material and was found to be independent of fluence, Figs. 5 and 6.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk3
evidence_span: The yield stress follows a similar behavior, Fig. 7 [11]; it saturates at about $0 . 3 \times 1 0 ^ { 2 5 } \mathrm { n } / \mathrm { m } ^ { 2 }$ .

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk3
evidence_span: In CANDU reactors, the temperature along the channel increases from about $2 5 0 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { C }$ at the inlet end to about 290 to $3 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { C }$ at the outlet end.

evidence_span: In CANDU reactors, the temperature along the channel increases from about $2 5 0 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { C }$ at the inlet end to about 290 to $3 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { C }$ at the outlet end.

evidence_span: As shown in Figs. 5 and 6, the crack velocities are higher at the inlet end than at the outlet end.

evidence_span: Shapes of cracks in early Pickering and Bruce reactors indicated that the rate of crack growth in the axial direction of the tube is about twice that in the radial direction.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk4
evidence_span: XRD analysis shows that enrichment of the $\beta$ -phase by niobium occurs during service and increases significantly from the inlet toward the outlet, Fig. 16.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk4
evidence_span: The enrichment is the result of a gradual decomposition of metastable 20 to 40 atomic percent niobium-enriched $\beta \mathrm { - } Z \bar { \mathbf { r } }$ towards a stable $\mathsf { \beta - N b }$ phase about 88 atomic percent niobium at $3 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { C } .$

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk4
evidence_span: X-ray diffraction indicates a variation in $\mathbf { \beta _ { < a > } }$ -type dislocation density along the length of the tubes, being highest at the inlet end and decreasing by about $20 \%$ toward the outlet end, Fig. 17.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk4
evidence_span: The data from samples taken from within $0 . 5 { \mathfrak { m } }$ of the centers of the tubes show that the $\mathbf { \delta } \mathbf { \leq a > }$ -type dislocation density has saturated by fluences of about $2 \times 1 0 ^ { 2 5 } ~ \mathrm { { n } } / \mathrm { { m } } ^ { 2 }$ ,Fig. 18.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk4
evidence_span: The crack velocity, $V ,$ of DHC in cold-worked $\mathbf { Z } \mathbf { r } { - } 2 . 5 \mathbf { N } \mathbf { b }$ is increased by a factor of up to five times, and $K _ { t H }$ is slightly reduced by neutron irradiation.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk4
evidence_span: The crack velocity, $V ,$ of DHC in cold-worked $\mathbf { Z } \mathbf { r } { - } 2 . 5 \mathbf { N } \mathbf { b }$ is increased by a factor of up to five times, and $K _ { t H }$ is slightly reduced by neutron irradiation.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk4
evidence_span: The effects saturate after about $1 \times 1 0 ^ { 2 5 } \mathrm { { n / m ^ { 2 } } }$

evidence_span: V decreases with increase in irradiation temperature.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk4
evidence_span: Neutron irradiation produces damage in the crystal lattice of $\mathbf { Z } \mathbf { r } – 2 . 5 \mathbf { N } \mathbf { b }$ in the form of predominantly type-<a> dislocation loops that harden the material.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk4
evidence_span: The irradiation hardening saturates at a fluence of about $2 \times 1 0 ^ { 2 5 } \mathrm { ~ n } / \mathrm { m } ^ { 2 }$ and so does the yield stress.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk6
evidence_span: in the radial direction in the irradiated material, follows the theoretical predictions based on a diffusional model for the $\pmb { \alpha }$ -phase and the change in yield stress with temperature and irradiation

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk6
evidence_span: In the axial direction, the dependence on test temperature does not follow the theory based on diffusion in the $\pmb { \alpha }$ -phase; the theory needs to incorporate a two-phase $( { \pmb { \alpha } } + { \pmb { \beta } } )$ diffusion model

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk6
evidence_span: Crack velocity decreases with irradiation temperature primarily through the change in the configuration of the $\beta$ -phase and, secondarily, through changes in dislocation density

evidence_span: smooth cantilever beam specimens were machined from cold-worked $\mathbf { Z } \mathbf { r } { - } 2 . 5 \mathbf { N } \mathbf { b }$ pressure tubes

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk7
evidence_span: Some of the specimens were gaseously hydrided at $4 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { C }$ to a hydrogen concentration of 40 to $1 2 0 ~ \mathsf { p p m }$

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk7
evidence_span: the remainder of specimens were tested with the as-received hydrogen concentration that was between 10 and 15 ppm

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk7
evidence_span: After loading, the specimens were heated to $3 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { C }$ and then cooled to the test temperature to reorient some of the hydrides under the applied stress

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk7
evidence_span: The as-received specimens were tested at $8 0 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { C }$

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk7
evidence_span: the hydrided specimens at either 150 or $2 5 0 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { C }$

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk7

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk7
evidence_span: cracks initiated at outerfibre stresses ${ > } 5 5 0  { \mathbf { M P a } }$

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk7
evidence_span: The range of failure times in these tests was between 53 and $6 6 0 0 \ \mathrm { h }$

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk8
evidence_span: In specimens with hydrogen concentration between 40 and 120 ppm, the crack initiation was not associated with any surface flaws or embedded particles.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk8
evidence_span: In these specimens, the cracks initiated at reoriented radial hydrides, near the surface of the specimen, at outerfiber stresses ≥ 413 MPa at a temperature of 150°C

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk8
evidence_span: and at stresses ≥ 585 MPa at 250°C

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk8
evidence_span: The range of failure times in these tests was between 2 and 1920 h

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk8
evidence_span: crack initiation by DHC at smooth (as-fabricated) surfaces in cold-worked Zr-2.5Nb pressure tubes requires a large tensile stress at a surface asperity or hydrides close to the surface and perpendicular to the stress direction.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk8
evidence_span: The microstructure of cold-worked Zr-2.5Nb pressure tubes consists of lath-shaped α-grains (hexagonal close packed) highly elongated in the axial direction.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk8
evidence_span: The α grains (with a thickness of about 0.5 μm) are surrounded by a continuous network of body centered cubic β-phase (about 0.05 μm thick and comprising approximately 7% volume fraction).

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk8
evidence_span: The α grains (with a thickness of about 0.5 μm) are surrounded by a continuous network of body centered cubic β-phase (about 0.05 μm thick and comprising approximately 7% volume fraction).

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk8
evidence_span: The α grains (with a thickness of about 0.5 μm) are surrounded by a continuous network of body centered cubic β-phase (about 0.05 μm thick and comprising approximately 7% volume fraction).

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk8
evidence_span: The original hydrides in this material are oriented parallel to the circumferential-axial plane along the α/β phase boundaries.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk8
evidence_span: The precipitation of hydrides in the hexagonal α-phase is known to occur on habit planes that are very close to the basal planes.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk8
evidence_span: The hydrogen concentration at the crack tip that is required for DHC initiation has to be greater than the terminal solid solubility (TSS) limit of hydrogen in zirconium for a given temperature.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk8
evidence_span: The Zr-2.5Nb material exhibits hysteresis between the heatup and cooldown TSS.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk8
evidence_span: TSS is also affected by the applied stress.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk8
evidence_span: Samples of Zr–2.5Nb and Zircaloy2 were prefilmed in steam (H₂O, 400°C at ~2 MPa and subsequently exposed to D₂O 10⁻³ Pa to ~18 MPa, and D₂ (~10⁻³ Pa) at a temperature range of 250 to 380°C in the laboratory.
